entries.title: MEC-01 Decision log with dissent
entries.summary: Capture high-stakes calls, dissenting views, and follow-ups so governance stays legible to teams and impacted people.
cues: Record why options were ruled out and who was consulted.
Attach plain-language summaries for external readers.
Set a review date tied to the stewardship window.
steps: Log the decision, rejected options, and who was consulted in one place.
Attach a short summary alongside the canonical record for external readers.
Set a review date with a clear owner tied to the stewardship window.
entries.policyRequirement:
Policy requirement (MEC-01 Decision log with dissent)
- Maintain a decision log for high-stakes changes with dissenting views and a dated review owner.
- Store the log in a shared system of record and retain links in audit and incident records.
Reference: https://ethotechnics.org/mechanisms/patterns/decision-log
entries.productRequirement:
Product requirement (MEC-01)
- Every high-stakes automated decision emits a decision-log entry ID in the receipt.
- The UI links to a plain-language summary within two clicks of the decision outcome.
entries.auditEvidenceChecklist:
Audit evidence checklist (MEC-01)
[ ] Decision log entries include owner, dissent, and review date.
[ ] Plain-language summaries are attached and shareable.
[ ] Stewardship reviews were completed on schedule.
entries.postmortemTrigger:
Postmortem trigger (MEC-01)
Trigger review if a high-stakes decision ships without a logged entry or dissent record.

artifacts.name: Decision record template
artifacts.purpose: Captures the decision, dissent, and follow-ups with owners.

artifacts.name: Plain-language summary
artifacts.purpose: One-paragraph recap teams can paste into briefs or release notes without jargon.

artifacts.name: Stewardship calendar entry
artifacts.purpose: Review reminder aligned to maintenance or appeal windows.

example.title: Recording a launch gate call
example.description: A cross-functional team logs why an automation launch was delayed, notes dissent from support leads, links the appeal path, and schedules a stewardship review in six weeks.

entries.title: MEC-02 Progressive consent prompts
entries.summary: Stage requests for data or automation over time, with reminders and exits that honor the consent journey.
cues: Pair each ask with why it is needed and how to revoke it.
Show impacts of opting out before a person commits.
Include a safety valve that defaults to privacy-preserving behavior.
steps: Break large asks into small prompts that explain why each is needed.
Preview what happens if someone opts out and keep the path visible.
Offer a safety valve that defaults to privacy-preserving behavior.
entries.policyRequirement:
Policy requirement (MEC-02 Progressive consent prompts)
- Stage consent requests with clear revocation paths and visible opt-out impacts.
- Document safety-valve defaults that preserve privacy when consent is withheld.
Reference: https://ethotechnics.org/mechanisms/patterns/progressive-consent
entries.productRequirement:
Product requirement (MEC-02)
- Each consent request includes purpose, duration, and revocation instructions.
- Opt-out paths remain visible and do not degrade core safety access.
entries.auditEvidenceChecklist:
Audit evidence checklist (MEC-02)
[ ] Consent journey map shows each ask, rationale, and rollback path.
[ ] Opt-out copy kit deployed across UI, email, and help surfaces.
[ ] Safety-valve defaults verified in staging and production.
entries.postmortemTrigger:
Postmortem trigger (MEC-02)
Trigger review if opt-out actions fail, are ignored, or re-enable without notice.

artifacts.name: Consent journey map
artifacts.purpose: Shows each request, rationale, and rollback path across the flow.

artifacts.name: Opt-out copy kit
artifacts.purpose: Short blurbs teams reuse in UI states, emails, and help docs.

artifacts.name: Safety valve checklist
artifacts.purpose: Confirms every step has a reversible, privacy-first fallback before shipping.

example.title: Piloting a model-powered assistant
example.description: Product and legal teams stage data collection prompts over several sessions, preview how opting out affects recommendations, and keep a global “pause automation” control visible in the UI.

entries.title: MEC-03 Maintenance windowing
entries.summary: Schedule improvements, monitoring, and resourcing using a visible stewardship window.
cues: Set owners and success criteria for each window.
Map communication cadences to risk levels and audiences.
Align dependencies so a degraded tool has a safe fallback.
steps: Define maintenance windows with owners, success criteria, and rollbacks.
Publish communication cadences by risk level and audience.
Check dependencies so degraded modes route to safe fallbacks.
entries.policyRequirement:
Policy requirement (MEC-03 Maintenance windowing)
- Publish stewardship windows with named owners, success criteria, and rollback authority.
- Require comms cadences by risk tier before shipping changes.
Reference: https://ethotechnics.org/mechanisms/patterns/maintenance-windowing
entries.productRequirement:
Product requirement (MEC-03)
- Release plans include a window ID and owner in change tickets.
- Status updates and fallback behavior are visible to affected users.
entries.auditEvidenceChecklist:
Audit evidence checklist (MEC-03)
[ ] Window calendar lists owners, coverage, and success criteria.
[ ] Comms templates are published by risk level and audience.
[ ] Fallback matrix confirms safe degraded modes for dependencies.
entries.postmortemTrigger:
Postmortem trigger (MEC-03)
Trigger review if changes ship outside the stewardship window or without comms.

artifacts.name: Window calendar
artifacts.purpose: Shared schedule with owners, coverage, and success criteria.

artifacts.name: Comms templates
artifacts.purpose: Prewritten updates for high, medium, and low-risk changes tied to roles.

artifacts.name: Fallback matrix
artifacts.purpose: Lists degraded modes and who is paged when dependencies fail.

example.title: Coordinating a stewardship sprint
example.description: Engineering and operations publish a two-week window with a fallback matrix, schedule status updates by audience, and rehearse degraded-mode protocols before shipping changes.

entries.title: MEC-05 Kill switch for runaway automation
entries.summary: Pre-authorized halt paths with named stewards, thresholds, and restoration drills so harms stop in seconds.
cues: Define triggers tied to moral performance indicators and frontline reports.
Name the people who can fire the switch and protect them from retaliation.
Rehearse rollbacks so halts land in reversible, well-communicated states.
steps: Map the automation path and mark where halts must land safely with owners.
Set tripwires for ethical interrupts that align with time-to-halt targets.
Run drills that practice firing, communicating, and restoring from the halt.
entries.policyRequirement:
Policy requirement (MEC-05 Kill switch for runaway automation)
- Maintain a pre-authorized halt path with a named roster and protection from retaliation.
- Publish tripwires tied to moral performance indicators and time-to-halt targets.
Reference: https://ethotechnics.org/mechanisms/patterns/kill-switch
entries.productRequirement:
Product requirement (MEC-05)
- The kill switch is reachable within one operational step from monitoring dashboards.
- Halt events emit receipts with owner, trigger, and restoration checklist links.
entries.auditEvidenceChecklist:
Audit evidence checklist (MEC-05)
[ ] Kill switch runbook names authorized operators and triggers.
[ ] Drill logs demonstrate time-to-halt performance.
[ ] Rollback checklists show safe restoration steps.
entries.postmortemTrigger:
Postmortem trigger (MEC-05)
Trigger review when time-to-halt targets are exceeded or the kill switch is unavailable.

artifacts.name: Kill switch runbook
artifacts.purpose: Documents triggers, authorized operators, and post-halt messaging.

artifacts.name: Rollback checklist
artifacts.purpose: Confirms data, access, and user impact are stable before resuming.

artifacts.name: After-action log template
artifacts.purpose: Captures what tripped the switch and how to tighten thresholds or observability.

example.title: Containing a runaway recommendation loop
example.description: Operations staff notice a spike in appeals and trip the kill switch, freezing recommendations, routing cases to humans, and restoring with updated thresholds before re-enabling automation.

entries.title: MEC-06 Appeal paths inside the UI
entries.summary: Give people a built-in channel to dispute outputs, get human review, or learn how a decision was made.
cues: Explain who reviews appeals and the expected response time.
Pre-fill context to reduce effort during stressful moments.
Track appeal outcomes to improve signal credibility.
steps: Place an appeal entry point near the affected decision with response times.
Pre-fill context so people can submit without rebuilding the story.
Track outcomes and feed them back into product and policy updates.
entries.policyRequirement:
Policy requirement (MEC-06 Appeal paths inside the UI)
- Provide an in-product appeal channel with published response timelines.
- Log appeal outcomes and feed them into governance review cycles.
Reference: https://ethotechnics.org/mechanisms/patterns/appeal-paths
entries.productRequirement:
Product requirement (MEC-06)
- Every appeal submission generates a receipt with response timeline and owner.
- Appeals are accessible from the decision surface without extra navigation.
entries.auditEvidenceChecklist:
Audit evidence checklist (MEC-06)
[ ] Appeal intake form includes pre-filled context.
[ ] Reviewer rota and escalation paths are documented.
[ ] Outcome log tracks response times and resolutions.
entries.postmortemTrigger:
Postmortem trigger (MEC-06)
Trigger review when appeal backlogs breach published response timelines.

artifacts.name: Appeal intake form
artifacts.purpose: Collects the minimum details with pre-filled context from the UI.

artifacts.name: Reviewer rota
artifacts.purpose: Lists who reviews appeals, coverage hours, and escalation paths.

artifacts.name: Outcome log
artifacts.purpose: Keeps decisions, response times, and fixes visible to teams and leadership.

example.title: Adding appeals to a risk scoring tool
example.description: The team adds an on-screen “Dispute this score” link with expected response times, routes submissions to a staffed rota, and logs turnaround data to improve credibility with regulators.

entries.title: MEC-07 Accountability latency tracker
entries.summary: Measure how quickly teams can intervene, halt, and restore systems when accountability is on the line.
cues: Instrument veto, halt, and restore events with owner and trigger metadata.
Publish accountability latency targets alongside time-to-halt SLAs.
Tie latency deltas to post-incident repair log entries.
steps: Define the telemetry contract for veto, halt, and restoration events.
Surface a dashboard that shows median latency and breach incidents.
Review latency drift during governance reviews and update runbooks.
entries.policyRequirement:
Policy requirement (MEC-07 Accountability latency tracker)
- Track veto, halt, and restore latencies with owner, trigger, and system context.
- Publish accountability latency targets in incident response runbooks.
Reference: https://ethotechnics.org/mechanisms/patterns/accountability-latency-tracker
entries.productRequirement:
Product requirement (MEC-07)
- Monitoring dashboards show accountability latency alongside time-to-halt metrics.
- Veto events emit receipts linked to the repair log and designated escalation owners.
entries.auditEvidenceChecklist:
Audit evidence checklist (MEC-07)
[ ] Telemetry captures veto, halt, and restore events with timestamps.
[ ] Dashboards report median and worst-case accountability latency.
[ ] Incident reviews include latency deltas and corrective actions.
entries.postmortemTrigger:
Postmortem trigger (MEC-07)
Trigger review when accountability latency breaches published targets or telemetry is missing.

artifacts.name: Telemetry contract
artifacts.purpose: Defines event names, required fields, and tags for observability tooling.

artifacts.name: Dashboard snapshot
artifacts.purpose: Shares latency trends and breach annotations for governance reviews.

artifacts.name: Latency response runbook
artifacts.purpose: Outlines response owners, escalation paths, and remediation steps.

example.title: Tracking veto response time during an incident
example.description: Operations teams add veto latency tracking to their Datadog dashboards, review weekly deltas, and tie missed targets to repair log updates and training.
